userreviews.userReview: Sena Jeter Naslund's courageous juxtaposition of two stories, two time periods, two styles urges us to seek parallels between a modern day writer and an eighteenth century painter, the writer having just completed a novel of the painter, Élisabeth Vigée-Le Brun, court painter to Marie Antoinette. With both narratives exploring marriage, husbands, children, and shining above all, their beloved work, one story is delivered leisurely in a single day, much like the contemplative Mrs. Dalloway; the other masterfully encompassing an entire life. Fascinating in structure and rich with detail, this is Naslund at her most delicately nuanced.Enjoy with me these lyrical sentences:-- Like dimly lit windows in the distance, ideas caught the edge of her attention for a moment, then winked out.-- Personifying Paris after the Revolution: The majestic city will glow and shudder around me, forgetting as best she can that blood and fear have swirled about her ankles.-- Regarding the fountain: Light, dressed in water, displayed itself as bright globules, as parallel lines and broken dashes, as continuous streamers, as spurts and gushes and splashes.And there's that gorgeous wedding night love scene! Oh my! And there are sentences full of wisdom:-- Yes, I am forever yoked to my husband, but this is the art of living: to feel what I feel; to be in no way repressed, mentally or emotionally; and to find the means both artistically and personally to let out the light that is within me. [Wow, what a powerful affirmation.]-- My father...used to say about his plays that the path to the universal was most certainly through the particular, but all great works, like a bridge, must place a foot on each shore, one concrete and one abstract.If you have time to linger over sentences, you will find much enjoyment in this novel.

I received this book for free through Goodreads First Reads.I vowed to finish this book even if it killed me. At around page 162, I thought it might:"Is this a day to make potato soup?" Janie asked cordially. Her voice had a juiciness to it, like an autumn-crisp apple, not a potato.The quote that sums up this book best is on page 296:"It's a beautiful neighborhood," Ryn babbled on. "Totally devoid of pretension, as unselfconscious as an old tree."This book is the exact opposite of that. The novel within the novel, historical fiction about Elisabeth Vigee Le Brun, is enjoyable. But its container novel is overly long and stuffed with too many characters, and the writing is so overwrought. "Ahab's Wife" is one of my favorite books, which heightened my disappointment.
This is proving to be a very difficult read, very self-aware and pretentious. Hopefully I'll be able to settle into it.

I find the idea of having two stories told within a book to be an interesting concept, where you have the stories of different characters being told and finding the connection between them. Unfortunately, as interesting as the concept may seem, my experience with it in real life haven’t been very positive. The main problem I have is that I find myself only enjoying one of the stories being told while either being bored or not liking the other character’s tale. This divide in interest and attention takes away from the overall enjoyment of the book. With The Fountain of St. James Court or, Portrait of the Artist as an Old Woman, I encountered this same problem, which made this book a big letdown for me.The book tells the stories of two strong female characters passionate about their works. The stories told switch from Katheryn Callaghan, an author, and French painter of portraits Élisabeth Vigée-Le Brun. For myself, I found the story of Élisabeth to be more interesting of the two. I thought her story was more vibrant where I can really feel how her passion for painting was ignited as a child and progressed through the years to where she became one of the most recognized portrait painters of her time. It was interesting to see how Élisabeth’s mind worked and the inspiration that went into her works. I just felt as if I got to know Élisabeth more thoroughly than I did with Katheryn. It was her narrative that I looked forward most to in the book.On the other hand, I am sorry to say that I was bored and a little confused with Katheryn’s story. During Élisabeth’s portion of the book, I got a sense that the story was moving and actually telling a period during her life, but with Katheryn I didn’t know where her narrative was taking me. I felt her story was more of one big inner monologue about her thoughts and ideas mixed with her reflecting on her past (the method in which we learn about her and her past). Now it wouldn’t have been a problem if the tone of her story wasn’t so flat. As I read through her parts of the book, I constantly found myself bored, wanting some spark from the narration to wake me up. Perhaps Naslund was going for a quiet and thoughtful tone with regards to Katheryn, but it didn’t hold my attention like Élisabeth’s story did.If both women’s tale captivated me on equal levels or as close to it as can be, this book would’ve worked for me. Like the last book I read involving telling the stories of two different women The Good Daughters by Joyce Maynard, the fact that only one story held my interest diminished the likeability of the book for me. The issue is further compounded by the monotonous tone of Katheryn’s tale, making it difficult for me to get through her portions of the book. There were moments where I can see the comparisons being made between these two women in regards to their passion for their works and what obstacles they had to overcome to continue writing and painting. But other than that, I didn’t see the need for the way the book is written. I just wished I could’ve become invested in both characters instead of just one and I think that would’ve made me the book more palatable to myself.*Received ARC edition from Goodreads First Read giveaway

Sena Jeter Naslund is a fantastic writer. She knows how to get into the soul of her characters so that her readers really connect with experiences and emotions. However, I was disappointed by this book. The pacing was tedious at times, and the plot seemed to drag. Points in the story that could have been engaging were instead brief mentions in a string of memories. Therein lies the fundamental problem with this book-- instead of feeling as though we are witnessing events in these women's lives, it feels as though we are being told a brief overview of important moments without being able to fully connect with them. It feels like you are sitting with an old woman, hearing her reminisce about her exciting life without being able to grasp the importance of the stories. I think a different format would have served the characters better.The sentences are beautifully crafted and there is some great imagery in the book, but at the end of the book it feels like nothing has happened. Marie Antoinette only briefly appears and although Vigee-Le Brun keeps saying that they had a strong connection, we never see it for ourselves and therefore we cannot entirely believe her. Vigee-Le Brun's life could have been portrayed as much more exciting and important than it was here.

The most amazing thing about this book to me was how it captured the way writers and artists relate to each other across geography and time. While on the surface, it seems as if the two novels woven together so astonishingly in this book are not related, they are deeply linked. Fountain, set in in contemporary times, features a writer, living in a neighborhood that surrounds a beautiful fountain, finishing a new book, still at the prime of her career while also growing older. Portrait follows a eighteenth century artist, who rose from humble origins to a great career as a painter, living through the tumultuous times of the French revolution. The relationship between these two geniuses, though not overt, crosses the boundaries of real time to show how profound are the ties that bloom between writers through their work. I also think Naslund can write sensory experience better than any living writer of our time.

I won't think of the French Revolution in the same way after reading this book. The past storyline, set in the years leading up the Revolution and then after, centers on a painter and her reflections on her life. The present storyline is about a writer who has just finished a novel about the French painter. They are both "old" women and it was interesting to have two main characters who frankly assessed the limits and benefits of their age. The book alternates these viewpoints, with the past storyline covering almost 80 years and the present storyline meandering over the course of a day. It was a bit jarring to go back and forth between such varied paces and the present day story did not hold my attention as well as a result. Still, Naslund is a gifted writer and quite a few of her sentences required reading again and pondering.

Ahab's Wife was the first book I read by Naslund. While the first chapters of this new book did not engage me as quickly as Ahab's Wife, I pressed on because of the power of Naslund's writing style.As a musician, writer, and novice painter, this book is a powerful read. Naslund has insights not only into the artistic processes of the painter, musician, and writer, she expresses depths of spirit that resonate deeply with my spiritual side. As an older woman, it was more difficult to read the stories of the aged women, and yet, here too she has important insights on the struggles and vulnerabilities one must face as one ages. Excellent read!

You know how the high end TVs today have a feature where there is a "picture within the picture" so you can watch two channels at once? The one larger picture being the main show you have interest in, and another smaller one that you can keep an eye on but is a distraction of sorts to the larger show. In much that same way, this story functions. It's a little lop sided journey through two narratives of thought concerning two separate women with a strand of similar reflective remembrances on their lives' bodies of work. I won this book as a Goodreads first read, and while there were parts of the story that pinged my interest buds, as a whole it fell a little short of my personal tastes. Certainly in fairness to the author, the writing is well done; for some readers I am quite sure the perspectives and themes of self discovery will ring more true.The more interesting profile is that of the revolutionary era French portrait painter Élisabeth Vigée Le Brun. Her story weaves through a relationship as painter for and friend to Mary Antoinette, an escape from the society of change afoot in the French Revolution, a life of wandering that eventually returns to the French countryside after the essential destruction of the society in which she was a part of before she fled. There are also introspective notions that tell her story as she might have reflected upon it late in life.The second, and less interesting tale from my perspective is that of an author who has just completed a rough draft for her novel outlining the details of the first woman's tale. This artist is a modern day author who lives in the non-fictional Victorian inspired St. James Court section of Louisville, KY. Her tale is more a memoir style story that interjects yet another set of late in life observations, thought tangents, and reflections. There are also seemingly out of placed storylines involving the interactions with family and friends who make up the life influences of the author. I think the approach here was to attempt to parallel these experiences with that of the first leading lady, but I think it took away from the more interesting story. The feminine voice in both stories is certainly strong; not a complaint, but I do think more direct identity will be found by readers who might have experienced the hurts, joys, and loves shared by both these female characters. So, for me it is a 2 star experience, for others it will be a much higher rated read as the author does a good job writing what will appeal to some more than others.

This book, The Fountain of St. James Court; or, Portrait of the Artist as an Old Woman: A Novel, by Sena Jeter Naslund, I discovered this was not your everyday biography. I was drawn to the book because of my appreciation of the artist, Élisabeth Vigée-LeBrun, who was an excellent painter and was fortunate to have painted portraits of Marie Antoinette & family. Naslund has chosen to write in a similiar style like James Joyce's A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man, (which I have yet to read). I'm grateful that the chapters are short.The modern story of the protagonist is intertwined with a character from the past whose own story also unfolds for readers to compare and contrast with the modern one. Readers are given the opportunity to follow 70 year old "modern" Kathryn, a writer, as she lives through an entire day after having completed a novel. Elizabeth's story is based on her entire life. Both Elizabeth and Kathryn have similar situations. * Both have only one child; Kathryn, a son and Elizabeth, a daughter. * Both characters have a close relationships with their mothers. Kathryn's mother is with her most of her life, while Elizabeth travels Europe to escape the revolution and is forced to leave her mother behind. * Marriage: Kathryn is three times divorced and Elizabeth is married only once. * When writing about Kathryn, or the "Fountain" chapters, readers also get some narration from some of Kathryn's friends and acquaintances. Elizabeth, from the "Portrait" chapters, is the only narrator in her story. I find myself reading only LeBrun's story because I find Kathryn's story a bit slow and lacking for me. I should have taken out "Elisabeth Vigee LeBrun: the odyssey of an Artist" by Gita May.

If this book had just been about the French female artist who lived during the time of the French Revolution, I most likely would have finished the whole thing. Her story, which discussed the artistic need to create, the nurturing of a talent, and a sense of vocation, was quite interesting. However, the second portrait (perhaps a self-portrait of the author, who also teaches writing and lives in Kentucky?) was a plot-less character study. It moved very slowly. There's one chapter where the character just lies in bed, musing over her past. Nothing wrong with some inner monologue, but while our historic character moved forward months and years, our present day character went hour by hour. While I think that the voice of women characters, especially older women characters, is not nearly as well represented in literature as it should be, I got bored and frustrated with this one. She seemed to dwell an awful lot upon either her failed marriage or her new romantic relationship. I would have liked to have heard more about how she saw herself as an artist, not as a wife/lover. Maybe I'll go back and just read the French chapters. Then I might finish at least that story.

Ugh, this kills me because Ahab's Wife is easily one of my favorite books ever, literally. But this just pales in comparison. The Elizabeth portions are told with such a light touch by the character itself that I felt like all I did was skim over the waters of her life without truly feeling the depths. The Ryn portions arguably have more depth, but her story is arguably less interesting also. I appreciate the Mrs. Dalloway approach of her story, though I feel like Naslund should have just committed and made nothing spectacular happen with the day; the confrontation that wraps up her story felt tacked on and unnecessary. And I know it sounds incredibly pedantic, but there is a reference to Bernini's very famous sculpture of Apollo chasing the nymph Daphne that claims that the female subject is the goddess Diana. I'm sure it'll get fixed in a later printing, but for a novel so much about art, it's a rather surprising mistake that is all the more glaring since it is put in the mouth of Elizabeth Vigee-Le Brun.

Terribly overwritten and under-edited. Only a few pages in, I found myself reading passages aloud to my husband, just so that he could laugh at the florid, self-important prose that dominates and obscures the story and characters. I was unable to finish the book because the more I read, the more the book felt like a parody of itself. If only the author was in on the joke, too.

I just finished The Fountain of St. James Court; or, Portrait of the Artist as an Old Woman: A Novel by Sena Jeter Naslund and do I ever have mixed emotions. Yes, Louisville friends, that is the real fountain at St. James Court on the cover. What I really enjoyed most about the book was the current day setting although it was tedious reading since it covered just one day. Having grown up in Louisville and attended the University of Louisville, this part of Old Louisville was like going home for me. Many, many times as students, my husband and I walked through St. James Court and Belgravia court admiring the homes and playing "One day..." Dr. Naslund mentioned Central Park and the tennis courts which is where my oldest brother played in many city-wide tennis tournaments. Dr. Naslund was a young professor at Louisville in the English Dept and although I never had her for a class, I remember seeing her whenever I was heading to classes. However, I thought that following the main character, Kathryn Callaghan, for one day made for tedious reading at times. It took almost two pages for her to walk up the steps in her home!!! I wanted to know more about the neighbors who seemed like nice characters.The story of Elizabeth Vigee-Le Brun, a French court portrait artist, made for better reading. She was a Her life was covered over years so much detail was left out but you got to know her better. She was a friend to Marie Antoinette and she somehow escaped the Reign of Terror during the French Revolution. She was also a devoted mother to her only child. On a side note here, the NYC Metropolitan Museum of Art is exhibiting Elizabeth's works and since we are now close to NYC, I look forward to seeing the exhibit. The notice of this exhibit showed up on my Facebook feed one day after I started reading the book. I have to wonder about the Facebook/Goodreads connection and the algorithms used!!! LOL!! All in all, it was a good read, especially reading and knowing the section of Louisville that was used. I'm not sure I will read another book by Dr. Naslund, but I will pass this one on to my nephew's girlfriend who also lives in Old Louisville.Go Cards! L1C4!!

For the past decade, Sena Jeta Naslund has been writing novels with distinctly literary themes, drawing on material first treated by such giants as Herman Melville (Ahab's Wife) and A. Conan Doyle (Sherlock in Love). Now she gives a nod to James Joyce and Virginia Woolf in The Fountain at St. James, or The Portrait of An Artist as an Old Woman.There are two female protagonists in Fountain, one imaginary and the other real. Kathryn Callaghan is a 21st century novelist who has just completed the first draft of a biographical novel. The subject of that novel is famed 18th century portraitist Elisabeth Vigee-Le Brun, who painted highly acclaimed works of Marie Antoinette and her courtiers. Kathryn's story takes place within a single day, as she takes stock of her life, now that she's in her sixties and contemplating how best to spend her final years. In doing so, she learns something about how far she will go to protect those she loves. Interspersed with Kathryn's experience is a reading of her new novel, told in the first person by the artist herself.Of the two lives presented here, Vigee-Le Brun's is by far the most momentous. As she dares to become the most pre-eminent female painter of her time, Elisabeth tells about her childhood with a much-loved father, her relationship with the Queen of France, and her flight from the horrors of the French Revolution. Along the way, she will lose the person she most loves, her daughter Julie. But to my mind, Kathryn's story is the more compelling one, as she comes to terms with love, loss, and age, and finds the courage to ward off a very real threat to the life of her own beloved son. While Elisabeth thinks of her life in visual, artistic terms, Kathryn relates hers to literature and its themes. But both spend considerable energy reflecting on the relationships that defined their work, their lives, and the choices that each made. As a novel, Fountain is deeply contemplative rather than action-based, and as a result, lags in many places. Still, the novel-within-a novel structure is interesting, and as always, Ms. Naslund's writing is eloquent and evocative.

At some points in the story, I found myself enjoying it, but at others I found it nearly unbearable. There are far too many tedious and unneeded details in the story of Ryn particularly. How is a chronicle of a woman walking around her neighborhood and her house all day interesting enough to keep a story going? It isn't. And the way other characters (like a neighbor moving in or a little girl who lost her father) are barely introduced but then short segments are written from their perspective - I get frustrated again just writing this. There is a constant promise that some of these characters are going to be important in the story or have some impact. Don't be fooled, they don't.The story of Elizabeth was better, but the same details of her life are repeated multiple times in many cases and near the end the story isn't chronological, and there are confusing details about her life too, that just go nowhere.In a few places the writing is beautiful and I get the feeling that Naslund was trying to make some point about women growing old, but I didn't quite get it. If I had to sum the book up in one sentence: Lots of detail of the obscure happenings of daily life that don't culminate in much of anything.

I was sure I'd love this since I am a huge fan of Naslund's other books. I expected a good historical fiction, but Naslund decided to write about the writer writing this story. Every other chapter is about the current day author, whose story is languorously written. We see her lying in bed, sitting on the commode, daydreaming about her 3 ex-husbands. It reminded me of Mrs. Dalloway, probably because Naslund kept mentioning Mrs. Dalloway, which, by the way, I hated.Maybe one day I will read just the chapters about the artist from Marie Antoinette's court. It's too slow going when interrupted by the author chapters. You definitely need to be in the right mood for this one and I just wasn't. I started something else that's much better, so maybe later.Gave it 54 pages before calling it quits.

This is marked as currently reading because I couldn't get through it. I read a lot of slow moving novels but found this one impossible. As many have said, the one novel was interesting, but the modern novel was pretentious - full of references (V. Woolf for heaven's sake, whose writing I adore)and arch comments that didn't really mean anything, at least to me. They just seemed an attempt to be clever. Even the story set in France didn't hold me, or else I'd have gone only to those chapters and skipped the others. I thought for sure there must be some relationship, a real one that would be revealed. Might have been but I couldn't stick with it. There are so many other books out there...

They say to give a book 50 pages before you give up. I read this until page 76. I agree with another reader who finds it pretentious and self aware. Wanted to scream at the main character to get the hell on with it. Early on there is a a seemingly random chapter with a couple walking a dog and a speeding car. As of page 76 they never returned and I have no idea why they was there, although it was the most interesting thing to happen up till this point. The child artist chapters were fine, but the modern author chapters were not. For me the story just never got going, and I did not engage with the author character enough to care.

I won this book in exchange for an honest review.My honest review is that I didn't much care for this novel. I found this novel to be extremely slow. At about page 200 I had to ask myself, where is this story going? And at that point I decided I just could not put myself through the chore of finishing it. However, the author is able to demonstrate her writing capabilities in this novel; evoking images using strong and lush prose. Unfortunately that skill did not enhance the story itself. The historical part of the story was interesting and I found myself just skipping to those chapters. Slow moving, uninteresting characters (in the present time) and convoluted prose.

It's an intriguing premise, but after reading just the teaser given at the end of "Abundance," I cannot imagine being able to get through this book. There was an absolutely heinous lack of editing. In the sample, I couldn't concentrate on anything said for the distraction of more than half the beginnings of sentences lacking capitalization, along with words such as "october" and "louvre." Add that to paragraph-long sentences paired with choppy two-word bits. I cannot imagine reading anything further by this author if something this maddeningly and distractingly poorly done is what she publishes as "incentive" to continue with her stories.

This book has two story lines. I liked one, and I didn't like the other at all. I tried to like it. Really, I did. But every time the story switched I found my mind wandering and then I noticed I felt mildly irritated and very bored. So I did something I'm not particularly proud of. At around page 150 I stopped reading the strange, uninteresting story line and finished reading only the interesting one for the rest of the book. This part was actually very good. Start reading this book and by 20 to 30 pages you'll know which part I gave up on.

I received this book in a First Reads giveaway from Goodreads. I haven’t read Naslund before, so I am not sure whether she adapted her writing style for this novel, but it took me awhile to accustom myself to it. See my complete review here:http://whatmeread.wordpress.com/tag/t...

I listend to this one, and the reader of the French artist's story was awesome. I just loved it. The writer's story? too self-consciously Mrs. Dalloway (which she kept pointing out to us) and a not-very-interesting, sort of contrived "scary" thing. But I'd recommend it as an audio-book just to hear the artist's story. That's the Sena-writing I know & love!

I read 100 pages and stopped. I am amazed at the difference in style between this novel and Ahab's Wife. I was not drawn into this story, cannot see how the story lines truly converge, and agree with others that this novel is too self-aware. It seems more like Naslund's self-reflection on her career thinly disguised as a novel.
I love the premise and idea of this book!!! Didn't enjoy the actual stories as much as the idea.

I can understand that some found this pretentious or confusing. Some may have a problem with the dual stories and the jumping time frames - I happened to love it, and thought it worked. The subject of two "mature" (a novelist and court portrait painter) and their passion for their respective art is a worthy and unexplored topic - the two narratives were entertaining, lyrical and very human. The settings (Old Louisville and Paris) were as much a part of the stories as the women themselves.

This was really two books within one book. I did enjoy this story, but I did find there to be a lot of repetition in the storytelling. I don't need to be reminded constantly about who a certain character is.Otherwise thought the writing was good.

The only reason this book didn't get 1 star is I still love reading about the French Revolution. But seriously when you take a whole paragraph to describe someone feeling a wart on their finger you've lost me.

Sometimes alternating chapters between past and present can be a rich experience, but in this book it falls flat. Especially the contemporary tale seems contrived and over sentimental. I would have been a lot happier with a historical novel just about Elisabeth Vigee- LeBrun,

description: How do writers and painters get their ideas? And what are the realities and heartbreaks that lie behind such seemingly glamorous and romantic lives? In her groundbreaking new novel, New York Times bestselling author Sena Jeter Naslund explores the artistic processes and lives of creative womenSena Jeter Naslund's inspiring novel-within-a-novel, The Fountain of St. James Court; or, Portrait of the Artist as an Old Woman, creates the lives of a fictional contemporary writer and of an historic painter whose works now hang in the great museums of Europe and America. Both women's creative lives have been forged in the crucibles of family, friends, society, and nation.The story opens at midnight beside a beautifully illumined fountain of Venus Rising from the Sea. Kathryn Callaghan has just finished her novel about painter Elisabeth Vigee-LeBrun, a French Revolution survivor hated for her sympathetic portraits of Marie Antoinette. Though still haunted by the story she has written, Kathryn must leave the eighteenth-century European world she has researched and made vivid in order to return to her own American life of 2012.Naslund's spellbinding new novel presents the reader with an alternate version of The Artist: a woman of age who has created for herself, against enormous odds, a fulfilling life of thoroughly realized achievement.
title: The Fountain of St. James Court; or, Portrait of the Artist as an Old Woman: A Novel
